prompt: We've got a tech giant from California wantin' to scrape our entire corpus of Gaelic literature to train their LLM. They say it'll save the language by makin' it digital, but they're no payin' a penny to the writers or the families of the bards who kept the tongue alive during the hard times. Is it cultural preservation or just colonial extraction all over again?

The new predictive text on the bairns' phones keeps correctin' perfectly good Gaelic grammar into English sentence structures. It's subtle, but it's changin' how the young ones form their thoughts. Should we be banin' these 'smart' keyboards in the Gaelic Medium schools to stop the anglicisation of the syntax?

An AI voice synthesiser has been trained on the recordings of a famous Lewis seanchaidh (storyteller) who passed away years ago. His family is upset that his voice is readin' news bulletins and weather reports he never spoke. Does the community own the voice of the tradition, or does the data belong to the archives that digitised it?

Duolingo is great for the tourists, but the elders are sayin' it's teachin' a 'standardised' Gaelic that ignores the rich dialects of Islay or Uist. If we let an algorithm decide what 'correct' Gaelic is, are we flattenin' our heritage just to make it fit into a database?

We have a chance to put Gaelic into a massive voice recognition system, but it struggles with the older speakers who have the deepest vocabulary. If the system only learns from the young ones with lighter accents, are we codin' ageism right into the revival efforts?

A chatbot has been released to help learners practice Gaelic, but it hallucinates idioms that don't exist. Now we have learners comin' to the Gaidhealtachd usin' phrases that make no sense, insistin' the computer is right. How do we police the purity of the language against a machine that sounds so confident?

Google Translate is finally addin' better Gaelic support, but it's crowdsourcin' corrections from anyone on the internet. We're seein' trolls deliberately feedin' it wrong translations. Do we need a 'digital council of elders' to gatekeep the data, or is that against the open spirit of the web?

There's a debate about 'Gaelic-ish' AI art—generatin' Celtic knotwork and patterns that look Scottish but have no actual meanin' or history. Is it harmless fun, or is it dilutin' our visual language with meaningless algorithmic noise?

The Council wants to use AI tutoring systems for Higher Gaelic because we can't find enough qualified teachers for the remote schools in the Highlands. Is it fair to the rural pupils to be taught by a machine while the Inverness kids get real teachers?

In the Gaelic Medium Units, the tablets provided by the government have operating systems that are only in English. The interface itself is teachin' the kids that English is the language of technology and Gaelic is just for history. Should we refuse the tech until it speaks our tongue?

We're seein' pupils usin' AI to write their Gaelic essays. The teachers canna always tell. If a lad uses ChatGPT to write a poem for the Mòd (Gaelic festival), and wins, has he cheated, or is he just usin' the tools of his time? What does this do to the oral tradition?

e-Sgoil (e-school) has been a lifeline, beam in' lessons to the islands. But now the council suggests closin' the physical village school entirely and goin' full remote to save cash. Is a school just a content delivery system, or is the buildin' the heart of the community?

There's new software for screenin' dyslexia, but it's calibrated on English phonics. It's flaggin' half our Gaelic Medium kids as havin' learnin' difficulties just because the sounds don't match the English model. Is it ethical to use these diagnostic tools on GME pupils?

A developer wants to gamify Gaelic history for the classroom, turnin' the Jacobite risings into an RPG. Some parents worry it trivialises the slaughter and turns our ancestors' struggle into 'points' and 'levels'. Where's the line between engagement and disrespect?

Digital textbooks are cheaper, but they can be updated instantly. We're worried a government in Edinburgh might quietly sanitise the history of the Clearances in the curriculum without us noticin'. Should we stick to print just to have a permanent record?

The internet filters in the schools are blockin' legitimate Gaelic cultural sites because the English-based algorithms misinterpret certain words or themes as 'inappropriate'. We're fightin' a firewall that doesn't understand our culture.

BBC Alba is movin' more content to iPlayer, but the broadband in the glens is shockin'. By switchin' off the broadcast signal eventually, are they disenfranchisin' the very heartland audience that kept the language alive, just to chase the urban demographic?

Social media algorithms suppress content that isn't in English because they can't moderate it easily. Our Gaelic influencers are getting shadowbanned for speakin' their native tongue. Do we demand transparency or build our own platform?

A production company wants to use deepfake tech to dub mainstream Hollywood movies into Gaelic. It might get the kids watchin', but it looks uncanny and weird. Is it better to have bad lip-sync and great Gaelic, or AI-generated lips that look real but feel fake?

Data shows that 'twee' content—Highland cows and Outlander fantasies—gets more clicks than real documentaries about crofting struggles. If MG Alba chases the clicks, we lose our authentic voice. How do we balance viability with truth?

Auto-captioning on videos is terrible for Gaelic, often producing offensive gibberish. But manual captioning is expensive. Is it better to have no subtitles and exclude learners/deaf audiences, or have AI subtitles that butcher the language?

Tourists are usin' Instagram geotags to find 'secret' wild swimming spots and fragile machair, causin' erosion and mess. Should we be askin' platforms to hide the location data of our most vulnerable landscapes?

There's an archive of old Gaelic songs digitised online, but it's behind a paywall owned by a university. The songs belong to the people, but the server costs money. Is it right to sell our own culture back to us?

Targeted ads are pushin' holiday homes in the Hebrides to wealthy folks in London and New York. The algorithm is actively acceleration' depopulation by marketin' our homes as investments. Can we petition ad networks to stop targetin' our housing stock?

They're digitisin' the records of the Highland Clearances. An AI analysis suggests some local families who claim to be victims were actually complicit. This data could tear the community apart. Do we publish the raw truth or let the sleeping dogs lie for the sake of social cohesion?

Ancestry websites are selling 'Clan Heritage' packages to Americans based on shaky algorithms. It's commodifyin' our history and turnin' clan connection into a generic badge for purchase. How do we protect the dignity of the lineage against commercial database mining?

A developer wants to build an Augmented Reality app that overlays the burning cottages of the Clearances on the modern landscape. Is this powerful education, or is it trauma porn that turns our ancestors' suffering into a spectacle for tourists?

We have 3D scans of the Callanish Stones. A video game company wants to buy the data to put the stones in a fantasy game where they get blown up. They own the scan copyright. Do we have moral rights over the digital twin of a sacred site?

DNA testing is revealing non-paternity events in the clan lines from 200 years ago. It's challenging the chieftainships and land claims. Should genetic data override centuries of oral tradition and established custom?

AI restoration of old photos from the 1800s is smoothin' out the faces of the crofters, makin' them look healthy and clean when they were starvin'. It's rewriting the visual history of our hardship. Should we ban AI 'enhancement' of historical archives?

Digital mapping of common grazings is being proposed to settle disputes, but the old boundaries were defined by rocks and streams known only to the locals. Putting it on a precise GPS grid removes the flexibility and negotiation that kept the peace. Is precision always better?

A project wants to record the 'last speakers' of a specific dialect. It feels like vulture capitalism—waitin' for them to die to monetise the recordings. Shouldn't the focus be on creatin' *new* speakers instead of archivin' the death of the old?

The ferry booking system is entirely online now, driven by dynamic pricing algorithms. The locals can't book a slot to get to the hospital because the tourists book them all up months in advance. Is it ethical for public transport to prioritise profit over lifeline services?

Remote working tech has brought 'digital nomads' to the islands. They earn London wages and outbid the locals for housing, but they don't contribute to the crofting work or the community events. Is high-speed internet saving the island or killing its soul?

We're lookin' at a community land buyout, and they want to run the vote via a secure app. But the oldest crofters don't use smartphones. If we move democracy online, are we disenfranchising the people who know the land best?

Telehealth robots are being trialled to check on the elderly in the remote glens. It saves the nurse a two-hour drive, but that visit was the only human contact that person had all week. Is efficiency worth the isolation?

The new wind farm is offering 'community benefit' payments via cryptocurrency to bypass bureaucracy. It sounds modern, but it feels like a way to dodge proper oversight and tax. Should a crofting community be dealing in crypto?

Drones are being used to monitor sheep on the hill. It saves the legs, but the skill of the shepherd and the dog is being lost. If we automate the croft, do we lose the connection to the animal and the land?

A datacentre wants to open in the Highlands, promising jobs and using our renewable energy. But it uses massive amounts of water and power, while locals are in fuel poverty. Are we becoming a battery for the world's data while we freeze?

Online genealogy groups are great, but now strangers from abroad are arriving and walking onto working crofts demanding to see 'their' ancestral home, ignoring the privacy of the people living there now. Does digital data create a false sense of ownership?
